feedback.Physical object: Excluded — The encoding targets the credential as institutional recognition, not the physical diploma.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Excluded — It is not a fabricated or constructed object, but a symbolic role assignment.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — A degree does not have physical fixity; its recognition persists independently of a medium.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — Not a structural system or form.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — The credential is abstract; perceptibility depends on instantiation (e.g., paper diploma).
feedback.Material form: Excluded — The concept itself is immaterial.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — Not meaningfully applicable to abstract status.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — It is granted deliberately to signify achievement and status.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — It does not generate or emit anything directly.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It does not involve transformation or control.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — It alters social standing, but not its own internal state.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — The recognition is socially interpreted, not interactive.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — While institutionally related, it is not a structural subsystem.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — It has no autonomous properties.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Not necessary for any system’s function.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — It signifies completion of educational criteria.
feedback.Communicative: Included — Encodes information about field, level, and issuing institution.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Excluded — Degrees result from a process governed by rules, but the degree itself is not a rule system.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — Does not consist of nested symbolic units.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Excluded — It enables opportunity but does not dictate behavior.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — Not reflective of its own structure.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — While time-dependent in issuance, the degree itself is not temporal.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Excluded — Its interpretation is relatively stable and codified across contexts.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — The degree is a cultural invention.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Institutions determine what it means and how it is granted.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Included — Strongly tied to personal and professional identity.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — Institutions define and issue degrees, but there is no single governing body or legal framework enforcing meaning.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Though it is a status, it results from formal instruction and is widely transmitted.
feedback.Visible: Excluded — The recognition is abstract; visibility applies only to physical instances (certificates, transcripts).
feedback.Context-sensitive: Excluded — Interpretation is relatively consistent across cultural and professional domains.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Universally recognized across academic and professional contexts.

encoding_notes: This encoding captures the degree as a symbolic, communicative social artifact, defined and transmitted by institutions but not intrinsically structured or perceptible. It has no active function but conveys highly consequential social identity.
